story:

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
Sadly, my dear dad passed away at the wonderful age of 84, on Saturday 23rd October 2021 at 10.28am. 

His final couple of days and hours were not nice for him, and I can say that I am glad to know he is now at peace, reunited with the love of his life, Mary his wife and my mum. 

Those that knew dad over the years will know that he held many amazing life changing careers, one of which he was always proud to share ~ being RNLI Crew member, Helmsman and maintenance mechanic, during the years of 1970 to 1985, saving a total of 162 lives. 

His final wishes were for a private cremation to take place.  Therefore, it will be private flowers only from family, and I thought it appropriate to set up an RNLI fund giving page for those still wishing to gift. Being based at Mudeford in Christchurch, Dorset, this is also where he met my mum Mary,  hence I think it’s an apt cause to donate to. 

If anyone would like to pay their respects by leaving a donation then please do… any amount in my dads memory, is so appreciated. 

May you all raise a glass and give dad a farewell toast, as I am sure you all share very different stories and memories. 

This is for you Dad ~ you will be very dearly missed.

story:
In 2010 the D-Class Inshore Lifeboat Ollie Naismith was officially named and went on service at Looe. The lifeboat was named after a popular local teenager Ollie Naismith who sadly died in a tragic road traffic accident in 2009. Ollies parents, Maxine and John Naismith spearheaded a fundraising campaign to raise the funds for the lifeboat which has gone on to save many lives in and around Looe including the life of Louis Webber, a young local lad who was of a similar age to Ollie. 

The lifeboat is now coming to the end of its operational life so the team at Looe Lifeboat station are teaming up with the Naismiths and Webber family to launch the Looe Lifeboat Appeal to raise the £78,000 required to provide a replacement lifeboat which will be named the Ollie Naismith II.

Your donation to this community appeal will help to fund this lifeboat which will continue the selfless work of our volunteer lifeboat crew in Looe.

I learnt about Organization - WWF - that helps in preserving the wild and Sea life. In my video I have prepared a project explaining the danger to wild life and sea life. I wish that we all join hands in preserving and love the beautiful nature and diversity of wild life and your contributions will help me together with WWF to achieve the goal. 


I sincerely hope that this little gesture of goodwill and sense of responsibility towards our own future will play an important part towards the cause that is now very dear to me.

Hope you will support me.

eventName: The Road to COP26 (and Back Again)
story:
I’m delighted to announce The Road to COP26 (and Back Again), a department wide charity event running through November. The key details are as follows:

  1. The challenge: how many times can the department get to Glasgow for COP26 (c.600km) and back again
  2. The how: colleagues contribute kms by any means (e.g. walking, running, cycling, rowing, swimming) and provide evidence (e.g. via Strava, Apple Fitness, Garmin Connect) so the department’s progress can be monitored
  3. The why: to support WaterAid – an international NGO providing clean water, decent toilets and hygiene knowledge to people who don’t yet have access to them.

Why WaterAid? Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

  • Access to clean water and toilets is a human right, and should be a normal part of daily life for everyone, everywhere
  • 771 million people don’t have clean water and 1.7 billion people don’t have a decent toilet
  • 31% of schools don’t have clean water and 443 million school days are lost every year because of water-related diseases
  • Every $1 invested in water and toilets returns an average of $4 in increased productivity
  • The World Bank says promoting good hygiene is one of the most cost-effective health interventions.
  • WaterAid and COP26: Climate change is making it harder for the world’s poorest people to get clean water. WaterAid are at COP26, urging leaders to act now to fix this.
